messages.content:
Explain this paper to me in depth using the Feynman technique, as if you were its author.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2507.23194

Geak: Introducing Triton Kernel AI Agent & Evaluation Benchmarks

Sureâ€”let me walk you through Geak (GEAK) as if I were the first author, using the Feynman technique: explain it simply, build intuition, then add detail, and finally show evidence and limitations.

What problem are we solving?
- Writing fast GPU kernels is hard. You typically need a GPU expert to pick tile sizes, manage memory hierarchy, avoid bank conflicts, coalesce loads, and adapt to each GPU architecture. Itâ€™s time-consuming and doesnâ€™t scale with the explosion of AI workloads.
- LLMs can write code, but â€œcorrect and fast Triton kernelsâ€ is a much higher bar than, say, Python scripts. General LLMs tend to produce kernels that donâ€™t compile, donâ€™t pass tests, or run slowly.
- We want an automated system that can: from a brief description, generate Triton kernels that are both correct and performant on AMD Instinct GPUs (MI300X, MI250), then verify them, and iteratively improve themâ€”without a human in the loop.

Our idea in one sentence
- Build an agent around a strong LLM that uses a structured loopâ€”generate, test, reflect, and optimizeâ€”plus inference-time compute scaling (multiple tries, feedback, and parallelization) to steadily turn rough kernel drafts into correct, fast kernels.

Why Triton, and why AMD GPUs?
- Triton is a Python-like DSL designed for kernels; it balances control and readability and is widely adopted.
- AMD Instinct GPUs power many modern AI stacks; to democratize performance across diverse hardware, we need automated kernel generation beyond a single vendor.

What is GEAK (the system)?
Think of GEAK as four cooperating roles around an LLM:

1) Generator
- Takes a short task description (e.g., â€œfused softmax over rows with dropout maskâ€) and any helpful context (a 1-shot similar kernel retrieved by code similarity, and a â€œknowledge packâ€ with Triton and hardware tips).
- Produces an initial Triton kernel.

2) Evaluator
- Stage 1: Functional tests. We compile and run with unit tests and fixtures. If it fails, we collect the error trace and observable outputs.
- Stage 2: If it passes functionally, we run performance tests (latency, memory behavior) against a reference.

3) Reflector
- Reads the failing code plus the error trace and explains what went wrong in plain language (e.g., â€œmismatched block pointer stridesâ€, â€œout-of-bounds due to tile size vs. shapeâ€).
- Proposes a concrete fix strategy. This guards against repeating the same mistake and helps the LLM escape the â€œdebugging trapâ€ where it keeps making the same fix.

4) Optimizer
- When code is correct, we shift to speed. The optimizer sees a ranked history of previous candidates and their timings and proposes a new optimization plan (not code yet): try different BLOCK sizes, vectorized loads, shared memory tiling, software pipelining, persistent threads, avoiding register spills, etc.
- The Generator then implements that plan into a new kernel variant.

Key techniques that make this work
- Inference-time compute scaling: we allocate more effort at inference: multiple iterations, parallel runs (temperature=1 for diversity), and pass@k selection. Accuracy improves roughly log-linearly with more runs.
- Reflexion-style loop: we write down â€œlessons learnedâ€ from crashes and errors into a short-term memory for the next attempt. This dramatically improves debuggability.
- 1-shot retrieval: we retrieve the most similar kernel by code similarity, not instruction similarity. Seeing a concrete, structurally similar Triton kernel is more helpful than a stylistically similar prompt.
- Knowledge injection: we augment prompts with targeted Triton and AMD ROCm/Mi300X tips (e.g., alignment constraints, wavefront sizes, LDS usage patterns, TMA/block pointer idioms, masking semantics).
- Anti-debugging-trap: if an attempt exceeds a max number of reflection cycles without progress, we force a fresh strategy to avoid looping.

What do we evaluate on?
We needed rigorous, GPU-targeted benchmarks that score both correctness and speed. We release two suites:

- TritonBench-revised (184 kernels)
  - Adapted from TritonBench-G; we fixed issues discovered on AMD GPUs (e.g., shared memory errors, HIP argument mismatches, missing function calls, inconsistent test harnesses). This yields a cleaner, stricter correctness signal.
- ROCm Triton Benchmark (30 kernels)
  - Real kernels from open-source AMD ROCm repos (e.g., Triton-based GEMM variants, layernorm, softmax, random ops, sorting/swizzle tests). These reflect practical, expert-authored patterns.

How do we measure?
- Correctness: unit tests must pass end-to-end. We also use pass@k to fairly account for multiple candidates.
- Performance: latency vs. reference on the same shapes/hardware; we report average speedups for correct kernels.

Main results
- Correctness:
  - On TritonBench-revised: up to 54.89% of tasks produce a fully correct kernel (vs. ~15% when directly prompting frontier LLMs without an agent loop).
  - On ROCm Triton Benchmark: up to 63.33% correctness.
- Performance:
  - On TritonBench-revised, GEAK-generated correct kernels achieve average speedup up to 2.59Ã— over reference baselines.
- Scaling:
  - We observe a log-linear scaling law with more inference-time attempts: more parallel/sequential runs â†’ higher pass rates.

What changed vs. naÃ¯ve â€œLLM writes codeâ€?
- The failure mode of direct prompting is â€œcompiles rarely; passes tests even more rarely; performance is an afterthought.â€ GEAKâ€™s loop changes the game:
  - Errors are treated as training signals at inference time.
  - We deliberately separate â€œfix bugsâ€ (reflector) from â€œget fasterâ€ (optimizer), so we donâ€™t prematurely tune performance on broken code.
  - We guide the optimizer with sorted historical candidates, which focuses the LLM on productive directions instead of random tweaks.

A concrete example of the loop
- Task: write a block-pointer matmul variant using Triton for MI300X with FP16 inputs.
  1) Generator drafts a tiling (e.g., BLOCK_M/N/K = 128/128/32) with prefetching and masks for edge tiles.
  2) Evaluator: tests failâ€”incorrect accumulation shape on fringe tiles.
  3) Reflector: identifies incorrect stride usage and masking in the last K-tile; proposes a corrected mask computation and pointer arithmetic.
  4) Generator applies fix â†’ tests pass.
  5) Optimizer: proposes trying different BLOCK_K and vectorized loads (ldmatrix-like patterns), adjusts num_warps, adds software pipelining hints.
  6) Evaluator times variants; the fastest passing kernel is selected.
  7) Parallel runs add diversity; pass@k increases the chance we find both correct and fast solutions.

What we open-sourced
- GEAK-agent: the multi-agent framework with Generator/Reflector/Evaluator/Optimizer, configs, and scripts to run on your data.
- GEAK-eval: the evaluation harnesses for the two benchmarks, including our fixes and standardized tests/perf runners.

Why the results matter
- Portable performance: With an agentic system, teams can target new hardware (here, AMD Instinct GPUs) without paying the full expert-optimization cost each time.
- Productivity: Instead of weeks per kernel, you describe intent and let the agent grind through the debugging and tuning loop automatically.
- Research direction: It shows that inference-time scaling and agentic feedback can substitute for specialized training in many cases, which is promising for â€œAI that accelerates AI.â€

Limitations and whatâ€™s next
- Not all kernels pass yet. Control-flow-heavy or numerically fragile kernels still fail at notable rates.
- Performance tuning is good but not always expert-level. Truly bleeding-edge performance (e.g., micro-architectural tricks, exotic prefetching) may need custom guidance or additional domain tools.
- Model dependence: stronger LLMs help. We experimented with multiple frontier models; results vary by backbone.
- Generalization: we focused on Triton on AMD GPUs; extending to CUDA, HIP bare-metal, or embedded accelerators will need adapted knowledge packs and evaluators.

Planned extensions
- Richer retrieval: structural program analysis to find not only similar code, but similar performance bottlenecks.
- Learned optimizers: have the optimizer learn which strategies worked historically for a given pattern/hardware.
- Multi-objective tuning: jointly optimize for speed, memory footprint, numerical stability, and energy.
- Broader benchmarks: more ROCm kernels and cross-vendor tasks, plus community submissions.

A quick takeaway for practitioners
- If you have a kernel-shaped need in Triton, GEAK can bootstrap you from a short description to a correct, competitive kernel and iterate toward better speed automatically.
- Use 1-shot retrieval, enable reflexion, keep a cap on debugging loops to avoid traps, and run parallel candidates to harvest diversity. Measure with pass@k.

Pointers
- Paper: arXiv:2507.23194
- Agent code: github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-agent
- Evaluation: github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-eval
- Overview blog (ROCm): â€œGEAK: Introducing Triton Kernel AI Agent & Evaluation Benchmarksâ€

If youâ€™d like, tell me a kernel you care about (e.g., attention softmax variant, fused norm+activation), and Iâ€™ll sketch how GEAK would approach generating and tuning it.

# GEAK: Introducing Triton Kernel AI Agent & Evaluation Benchmarks

Jianghui Wang111Primary authors\\AndVinay Joshi111Primary authors\\AndSaptarshi Majumder
\\AndXu Chao
\\AndBin Ding
\\AndZiqiong Liu
\\AndPratik Prabhanjan Brahma
\\AndDong Li
\\AndZicheng Liu
\\AndEmad Barsoum
\\ANDAdvanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD)

###### Abstract

The demand for AI-generated GPU kernels is rapidly growing, influenced by the need for scalable, hardware-optimized solutions in both industry and academia. As deep learning workloads grow in complexity and diversity, it is imperative to automate low-level kernel development to meet performance and productivity demands. Major cloud providers, semiconductor companies, and research institutions are now investing heavily in AI-driven code generation for GPUs, aiming to reduce manual optimization efforts while achieving near-expert performance on hardware like AMDÂ Instinctâ„¢Â MI300X. The Triton language, a Python-based DSL for GPU programming, has emerged as a popular target for such AI-generated kernels due to its balance of performance and ease-of-coding. In this work, we present an evaluation suite for Triton-based GPU kernels and GEAK (Generating Efficient AI-centric GPU Kernels)â€”a framework that leverages cutting-edge LLMs to generate performant Triton code specifically for AMD GPUs, including the AMD Instinctâ„¢ MI300X and MI250. GEAK leverages inference-time compute scaling to produce Triton-based GPU kernels using a reasoning loop adapted from Reflexion-style feedback mechanisms. On two evaluation benchmarks, GEAK significantly outperformed the baselines of directly prompting frontier LLMs as well as Reflexion-based generation pipelines by achieving correctness up to 636363% and execution speed up of up to 2.59X. These results highlight the promise of GEAK-like agentic code generation for accelerating the adoption of diverse hardware platforms and democratizing access to expert-level kernel performance.

_K_ eywordsâ€‚Triton language Â â‹…\\cdotâ‹…
GPU kernel generation Â â‹…\\cdotâ‹…
Automated Code Generation Â â‹…\\cdotâ‹…
Inference time scaling

## 1 Introduction

Figure 1: Illustration of GEAK pipeline.

As AI workloads scale in both complexity and hardware diversity, there is a growing demand for intelligent systems that can generate high-performance GPU kernels without manual tuning. This demand is especially critical in environments where tight coupling between software and hardware efficiency determines practical feasibilityâ€”ranging from hyperscaler data centers used for serving frontier LLMs to academic HPC clusters. Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) have shown promising capabilities in code generation tasks, but achieving correct and efficient GPU code remains an open challenge. AI-assisted GPU kernel development, particularly for emerging hardware like AMD Instinctâ„¢ MI300X GPUs, can substantially improve productivity and deployment speed.

To this end, we introduce GEAK (Generating Efficient AI-centric GPU Kernels), AMDâ€™s new agentic framework for automatic Triton kernel generation targeting AMD Instinctâ„¢ GPUs. GEAK is built to push the frontier of AI-assisted code generation by combining state-of-the-art LLMs with a structured reasoning and feedback loop. Alongside GEAK, we release two benchmark suites for evaluating AI-generated Triton kernels, enabling measurement of both execution correctness and runtime performance of generated kernels.

Key Contributions:

1. 1.


We introduce GEAK framework, a modular, agent-based system that uses inference-time compute scaling with frontier LLMs to generate Triton GPU kernels from minimal task descriptions. GEAK incorporates multiple agentsâ€”generation, evaluation, reflection, and optimizationâ€”to iteratively refine code quality and execution performance.

2. 2.


We establish two benchmark suites for evaluating Triton kernel generation. The TritonBench-revised is a revised subset of 184 kernels adapted from TritonBench-G\[ [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib1)\] with stricter testing harnesses. In addition, we release the ROCm Triton Benchmark, a new suite of 30 real-world kernels sampled from open-source AMD ROCm repositories.

3. 3.


We demonstrate that GEAK significantly outperforms direct prompting of state-of-the-art LLMs, achieving correct kernel generation rate up to 54.8954.8954.89% on TritonBench-revised and 63.3363.3363.33% on the ROCm Triton benchmarkâ€”compared to less than 151515% when directly prompting strong LLMs without agentic feedback.

4. 4.


We also present a detailed study on one of the performant kernels from ROCm Triton Benchmark (please see Appendix [A](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#A1)).

5. 5.


We open source our GEAK agent implementation ( [github link](https://github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-agent)) and GEAK evaluation framework ( [github link](https://github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-eval)).


Furthermore, GEAK-generated kernels demonstrate an average speedup of up to 2.592.592.59Ã— over their reference counterparts on the TritonBench-revised set.

## 2 Related Work

##### Benchmarks

As program synthesis research advances, the need for rigorous and multidimensional benchmarks has become increasingly important. Most existing coding benchmarks concentrate on functional correctness, often assessed through manually crafted test cases and isolated execution environments. For instance, HumanEval provides expert-written programming tasks paired with curated test suites, while MBPP\[ [2](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib2)\] collects problems through crowdsourcing. To improve coverage and scalability, more recent approaches have turned to automated test generation\[ [3](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib3)\], enabling broader application in areas such as software engineering and developer assistance\[ [4](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib4)\].

In addition to correctness, performance profiling is gaining traction as a crucial axis in benchmarking (\[ [5](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib5)\];\[ [3](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib3)\];\[ [6](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib6)\];\[ [7](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib7)\]). However, most existing frameworks emphasize competition-style tasks or sequential execution and provide limited support for parallel or hardware-specific evaluation. While a few benchmarks address parallel CPU programming (\[ [8](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib8)\];\[ [9](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib9)\]), GPU-targeted benchmarks remain scarce, despite the growing importance of hardware efficiency in deploying large-scale deep learning models.

To address this gap, benchmarks like KernelBenchÂ \[ [10](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib10)\] and TritonBenchÂ \[ [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib1)\] have emerged, offering domain-specific assessments of LLM performance on GPU kernel generation. KernelBenchÂ \[ [10](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib10)\] focuses on correctness and runtime efficiency across diverse workloads using metrics like "fast\_p", while TritonBenchÂ \[ [1](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib1)\] highlights the challenges LLMs face in generating performant code for the Triton DSL. These benchmarks reveal a substantial gap between general-purpose code generation and the demands of high-performance, hardware-aware synthesis, underscoring the need for specialized, compute-oriented evaluation frameworks.

##### LLMs for Code Generation

More recent work has explored the use of large language models for code generation, but often in general-purpose contexts with limited success on performance-critical low level code, such as DeepSeek-Coder\[ [11](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib11)\] and Qwen-Coder\[ [12](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib12)\], which have achieved strong performance on broad coding benchmarks.

There are also LLMs specifically trained for the kernel generation task, such as KernelLLM. However, its capability is limited to translating PyTorch code into Triton kernels, restricting its general applicability. In contrast, our agent can generate Triton code based on both natural language instructions and reference code, allowing for more flexible and context-aware code synthesis. Furthermore, specialized models like KernelLLM often lack the broader reasoning and problem-solving capabilities exhibited by larger state-of-the-art LLMs such as GPT-4.1 and Claude 4, which are critical for tackling complex optimization tasks involving multiple constraints and trade-offs.

##### Inference-Time Compute Scaling

Inference-time compute scaling refers to the strategy of allocating increased computational resourcesâ€”such as longer context windows, multiple reasoning passes, or parallel generations â€” during the inference phase of machine learning models to boost performance on complex tasks.
Notably, this approach enables significant improvements in large language model (LLM) performance without requiring additional training.
For example, the Chain-of-ThoughtÂ \[ [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib13)\] prompting technique enhances reasoning by encouraging models to answer questions in a step-by-step manner. Similarly, the ReflexionÂ \[ [13](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.23194v1#bib.bib13)\] framework improves agent performance by integrating verbalized feedback into an episodic memory buffer, which guides more informed decision-making in future attempts.
Our proposed GEAK agent also leverages inference-time compute scaling to improve code generation and optimization quality. In addition, we incorporate a Reflexion-style module for debugging, enabling the agent to iteratively refine its outputs based on past execution feedback.

## 3 Benchmarks

We experiment with Triton kernel evaluation benchmarks, consisting of a modified set of 184 kernels originally sourced from TritonBench-G and an additional set of

As the demand for AI-generated GPU kernels increases due to the complexity of deep learning workloads, GEAK aims to streamline kernel development by leveraging advanced large language models (LLMs) to produce optimized Triton code specifically for AMD GPUs, including the MI300X and MI250.

The framework employs a structured reasoning loop and inference-time compute scaling to enhance the quality and performance of generated kernels. # GEAK: Introducing Triton Kernel AI Agent & Evaluation Benchmarks

## Contents

# GEAK: Introducing Triton Kernel AI Agent & Evaluation Benchmarks [\#](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/rocm.blogs.amd.com\#geak-introducing-triton-kernel-ai-agent-evaluation-benchmarks)

August 01, 2025 by [Jianghui Wang](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/jianghui-wang.html), [Vinay Joshi](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/vinay-joshi.html), [Saptarshi Majumder](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/saptarshi-majumder.html), [Chao Xu](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/chao-xu.html), [Bin Ding](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/bin-ding.html), [Ziqiong Liu](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/ziqiong-liu.html), [Pratik Prabhanjan Brahma](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/pratik-prabhanjan-brahma.html), [Dong Li](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/dong-li.html), [Zicheng Liu](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/zicheng-liu.html), [Emad Barsoum](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/emad-barsoum.html).

10 min read. \| 2414 total words.

[Software tools & optimizations](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/blog/category/software-tools-optimizations.html)

[AI/ML](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/blog/tag/aiml.html)

[Developers](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/developers.html), [AI](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/ai.html)

At AMD, we are pioneering ways to accelerate AI development using AI itself, by generating accurate and efficient GPU kernels. Specifically, we are starting with the automatic generation of kernels in [Triton](https://triton-lang.org/main/index.html), an open-source Python-like language for writing parallel programming code for GPUs. Today, AMD is excited to announce (a) [Generating Efficient AI-centric Kernels (GEAK)](https://github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-Agent) for AMD GPUs, and results on (b) two Triton kernel evaluation benchmarks, where we show how AI agents can perform inference-time scaling with frontier LLMs to generate accurate and efficient kernels for AMD Instinctâ„¢ GPUs like MI250X and MI300X.

**Key Takeaways:**

- Announcing [GEAK Triton kernel generation framework](https://github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-Agent), a library of various types of agentic AI and scaling methods to automatically produce Triton kernels from just brief instructions of its intended functionality.

- Announcing corresponding [GEAK Triton Kernel Evaluation Benchmarks](https://github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-eval), consisting of a modified set of 184 kernels originally sourced from [TritonBench-G](https://arxiv.org/abs/2502.14752) \[1\] and an additional set of 30 kernels from various open [ROCm repositories](https://github.com/ROCm).

- Execution accuracy up to 54.89% on TritonBench-modified and 63.33% on ROCm benchmark (as compared to around 15% when directly prompting frontier LLMs) in producing correct kernels that pass all the unit tests.

- Average Speedup of up to 2.59X with the AI-generated kernels over reference kernels from the TritonBench-modified benchmark.


Figure 1. Overview of the GEAK kernel code generation AI agent [#](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/rocm.blogs.amd.com#id1)

As shown in Figure 1, the agentic AI system comprises four core modules: a **generator**, a **reflector**, an **evaluator**, and an **optimizer**.

- The **generator** produces code based on user query and contextual information.

- The **evaluator** follows a cascaded design: it first performs a functionality test to verify correctness. If the code fails this test, the corresponding error trace is fed back to the reflector for further analysis. If the code passes, the evaluator proceeds to assess its performance, including latency and memory efficiency.

- If the generated code fails to execute correctly, the **reflector** analyzes both the code and the resulting error trace to identify potential issues.

- Finally, the **optimizer** takes as input the functionally correct code and formulates strategies to enhance its performance with respect to latency and computational efficiency.


To improve the performance of our agent, we employ some composable and configurable techniques as mentioned below:

- **1-shot Prompting**


To enable 1-shot prompting, the most similar Triton code from existing datasets is used in the prompt. The datasets used for 1-shot prompt do not overlap with the benchmark. Weâ€™ve observed that 1-shot sample retrieval from datasets is most effective when using code similarity rather than instruction similarity.

- **Knowledge Injection**


We enhance the prompt with domain-specific knowledge on writing efficient Triton kernels, including detailed hardware specifications. This incorporation of low-level optimization principles significantly improves the accuracy and quality of LLM-generated code.

- **Reflexion**


To enhance the systemâ€™s self-correcting capabilities, we leverage a reflexion \[3\] module that supports introspective debugging and iterative refinement. When an LLM-generated kernel fails the functionality test, the resulting error trace is provided as feedback to the reflector for further analysis and correction. The agent is tasked with analyzing the cause of failure and proposing a corresponding solution. We scale the number of iterations to improve kernel generation.

- **LLM selection for kernel agent**


We have explored the use of multiple LLMs like GPT-4.1, GPT-o1, and Gemini 2.5 Pro. We observed notable variations in the output produced by different models, indicating that the capability of the underlying LLM can substantially influence the results. In this blog, we present results with GPT-4.1 only but the GEAK codebase allows developers to try different LLMs as per their choice.

- **LLM as Optimizer**


The optimizer is tasked with identifying potential optimization directions based on previous code generations and their corresponding performance metrics. These historical records, which include the generated code and associated performance results, are sorted in ascending order of performance. This structured presentation \[2\] helps guide the LLM toward proposing more effective optimization strategies.

- **Debugging Trap**


When LLMâ€™s generated code has bugs, the error trace is provided to the Reflector for feedback generation for further correction. However, weâ€™ve observed that sometimes code can undergo several reflection cycles while still being plagued by the same bug, which is what we refer to as the debugging trap. To prevent the agent from getting stuck in a debugging trap, we impose a limit on the number of debugging attempts per code snippet using a parameter max\_perf\_debug\_num. If the code continues to fail after reaching this threshold, the agent is required to discard the current approach and generate a new strategy along with fresh code.

- **Parallel Scaling**


To ensure reliable kernel generation, we run multiple instances of GEAK multiple times in parallel and independently. To introduce diversity in the generated code, the LLM output is sampled with the parameter temperature set to 1. Our experiments show that such diversity in generation can yield correct and faster kernels that are otherwise underexplored. Moreover, further experiments indicate that combining sequential and parallel scaling yields additional performance improvements. To obtain unbiased estimates of accuracy, we use the pass@k metric to estimate it \[4\].

## Triton Kernel Evaluation Benchmark [\#](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/rocm.blogs.amd.com\#triton-kernel-evaluation-benchmark)

We conducted experiments using two benchmarks methods:

**1\. TritonBench-Modified Benchmark (184 Kernels):**

The Triton kernels and corresponding evaluation codebase were adapted from [TritonBench](https://github.com/thunlp/TritonBench) \[1\] with several modifications made:

- Out of 184 kernels in TritonBench-G, we identified and corrected errors in 37 kernels that were encountered when running on AMD GPUs. These errors include shared memory errors, invalid HIP arguments, and ModuleNotFound errors.

- We found that several kernels in the original TritonBench repository missed necessary call functions, which resulted in the accuracy checking code comparing empty strings as output. We corrected this and ensured that the correct common seed was used during test.

- For some kernels, testbenches were written inconsistently that produced unexpected outputs. We have fixed these kernels to have consistent testbenches.


**2\. ROCm Repository Triton Benchmark (30 Kernels):**

The benchmark contains 30 kernels chosen from various open ROCm repositories that have been written by Triton expert engineers and released publicly to help enable the ecosystem around running AI workloads efficiently on AMD GPUs. The entire list of kernels is outlined in Table 1. We also took assistance from frontier LLMs to put these kernels, as well as their corresponding unit tests, in the same format as the TritonBench-modified framework. It allows us to compare the accuracy and efficiency of our agent consistently.

| **ROCm Kernel** | **Repository link** |
| --- | --- |
| 1\. test\_tma\_store\_gemm 2. moe-gemm 3. layernorm 4. triton\_multreduce\_matmul\_kernel.py 5. multreduce\_matmul\_dot\_kernel.py 6. gemm 7. test\_block\_pointer\_matmul 8. test\_block\_copy 9. test\_add\_kernel 10. softmax | [ROCm/triton](https://github.com/ROCm/triton/tree/main_perf) |
| 1\. mnsnorm\_fwd 2. rmsnorm\_bwd 3. test\_chained\_dot\_fp8 4. test\_matmul\_MXFP 5. test\_gemm\_fusion | [ROCm/aiter](https://github.com/ROCm/aiter) |
| 1\. test\_triton\_swizzle2d 2. test\_triton\_sort 3. test\_triton\_flip 4. test\_reverse\_range | [ROCm/aotriton](https://github.com/ROCm/aotriton) |
| 1\. test\_load\_reduce.py 2. test\_chained\_matmul | [ROCm/vllm](https://github.com/ROCm/vllm) |
| 1\. test\_random\_int 2. test\_randn 3. test\_kernel\_sub 4. test\_kernel\_dot 5. test\_batched
result.summary:
The webpage introduces GEAK, a new AI agent framework developed by AMD for generating efficient GPU kernels using Triton, an open-source programming language. The framework aims to enhance AI development by automating the creation of kernels from brief functional instructions. Key features include:

- **GEAK Triton Kernel Generation Framework**: A library that utilizes various AI methods to produce Triton kernels efficiently.
- **Evaluation Benchmarks**: The framework includes two benchmark sets, with execution accuracy rates of 54.89% and 63.33% on modified Triton and ROCm benchmarks, respectively, significantly outperforming traditional methods.
- **Performance Improvements**: AI-generated kernels show an average speedup of 2.59 times compared to reference kernels.

The system consists of four modules: a generator for code creation, an evaluator for testing functionality and performance, a reflector for analyzing errors, and an optimizer for refining the code. This innovative approach aims to streamline the development of AI applications on AMD GPUs.
result.title: GEAK: Introducing Triton Kernel AI Agent & Evaluation Benchmarks

[Zicheng Liu](https://www.linkedin.com/in/zicheng-liu?trk=public_post_feed-actor-name)

# Computer Science > Artificial Intelligence

**arXiv:2507.11633** (cs)

\[Submitted on 15 Jul 2025\]

# Title:General Modular Harness for LLM Agents in Multi-Turn Gaming Environments

Authors: [Yuxuan Zhang](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Zhang,+Y), [Haoyang Yu](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Yu,+H), [Lanxiang Hu](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Hu,+L), [Haojian Jin](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Jin,+H), [Hao Zhang](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Zhang,+H)

View a PDF of the paper titled General Modular Harness for LLM Agents in Multi-Turn Gaming Environments, by Yuxuan Zhang and 4 other authors

[View PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2507.11633) [HTML (experimental)](https://arxiv.org/html/2507.11633v1)

> Abstract:We introduce a modular harness design for LLM agents that composes of perception, memory, and reasoning components, enabling a single LLM or VLM backbone to tackle a wide spectrum of multi turn gaming environments without domain-specific engineering. Using classic and modern game suites as low-barrier, high-diversity testbeds, our framework provides a unified workflow for analyzing how each module affects performance across dynamic interactive settings. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the harness lifts gameplay performance consistently over un-harnessed baselines and reveals distinct contribution patterns, for example, memory dominates in long-horizon puzzles while perception is critical in vision noisy arcades. These findings highlight the effectiveness of our modular harness design in advancing general-purpose agent, given the familiarity and ubiquity of games in everyday human experience.

## Technical report

## Introduction

This is an LLM-based multi-agent framework, which can generate functional and efficient gpu kernels automatically.

The framework is extendable and flexible. You can easily make you own coding agent and test it on our GEAK-eval [https://github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-eval](https://github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-eval).
We provide a baseline agent to let you run directly.

## GEAK-agent

It contains a Generator, a Reflector, an Evaluator and an Optimizer. The actor generates codes according to the query and context information. The Reflector is responsible for reflecting on the generated code and the error trace if the code failed to run. The Evaluator has a cascade structure. It tests the generated code for the functionality first. If the generated code doesn't pass the functionality test, the error trace will be fedback to the Reflector. Otherwise, the Evaluator will evaluate the performance including latency and efficiency. The Optimizer gets the generated codes, which pass the evaluator's tests, and gives a strategy to optimize the code in terms of latency and efficiency.

### the Optimizer

We provide previous generated codes as reference codes with their corresponding performance to the Optimizer. The number of reference codes is controlled by the arg `ancestor_num`. The reference codes are arranged in ascending order to help the Optimizer LLM find the optimization direction. We don't ask the LLM to generate new codes directly from the reference codes, instead we ask the Optimizer to analyze the reference codes first and to generate a promising strategy to optimize the code. Then we feed the generated optimization stratgey to the Generator to generate new codes.

### debugging trap

LLMs frequently get caught in debugging traps. When their generated code has bugs, we provide the error trace to the Reflector correction. However, we've observed that sometimes code can undergo several reflection cycles while still being plagued by the same bug. We refer to this as a debugging trap.

To prevent the LLM from getting stuck in a debugging trap, we limit debugging attempts per code snippet using `max_perf_debug_num`. If the code fails after this many fixes, the agent must abandon the current approach and generate a fresh strategy and code.

## Run the Agents

1. prepare the environment



```
python3 -m pip install -r requirements.txt

```

2. go to the src/ folder



```
cd src

```

3. edit config file. You need to give your API key and TritonBench data path in your config file.



```
cp configs/tritonbench_optimagent_config.yaml configs/tritonbench_optimagent_config_new.yaml

```

4. put the config file in the main\_optimagent.py and run the script



```
python main_optimagent.py

```


### Resuming from Checkpoints

Result and memories will be stored in the `output_path` specified in the config file for each iteration. You can resume from any iter you want by specifying the `result_file`, `mem_file` and `start_iter` in the config file. For example:

```
result_path: "../outputs/optimagent_10.jsonl"
mem_file: "../outputs/optimagent_mem_10.json"
start_iter: 11

```

## How to use your own data

1. create a new file for your own dataloader in dataloaders



```
touch dataloaders/OnlineData.py

```

2. In your own dataloader, define a new data class



```
class OnlineData:

```

3. In the OnlineData, you need load `problem_states`, which is a list of ProblemState instances. To meet the minimum requirement, each ProblemState instance should include the following fields: `instruction`, `filename`, `test_code`.

4. In order to use OptimAgent, the OnlineData class must implement the following methods:



```
__len__() -> int
test_opt_correctness(code, filename, tmp_dir, exe_dir) -> pass_call, pass_exe, call_stdout, call_stderr, exe_stdout, exe_stderr
write_perf_file(input_folder_path, results_path, tmp_dir) -> None
run_perf_scripts(gpu_id, script_dir, log_dir) -> None
write_file(file_path) -> None


```





### Method Description



 - \_\_len\_\_()

 Returns the number of problem\_states in the dataset.

 - test\_opt\_correctness(code, filename, tmp\_dir, exe\_dir)

 Tests whether the generated code is functionally correct.

 Parameters:



 ```
 code: The generated code to be tested.

 filename: Name of the test script file.

 tmp_dir: Directory to save the script (generated code + unit test).

 exe_dir: Directory to store scripts that pass execution tests.

 ```



 Returns:



 ```
 ass_call: True if the script runs without errors.

 pass_exe: True if the script produces the correct output.

 call_stdout, call_stderr: Stdout and stderr from the initial script execution.

 exe_stdout, exe_stderr: Stdout and stderr from the execution verification step.

 ```



 Note:



 ```
 You might need to provide a Python file containing both the golden code and unit test code, separated by a line of exactly 146 hash (#) symbols. The unit test will be appended to the generated code for validation.

 ```

 - write\_perf\_file(input\_folder\_path, results\_path, tmp\_dir)

 Generates performance test scripts using the code in input\_folder\_path (which is typically the same as exe\_dir from test\_opt\_correctness). The function will append unit tests for performance tests to the generated codes and store the scripts in tmp\_dir. The performance test results will be saved in results\_path.

 - run\_perf\_scripts(gpu\_id, script\_dir, log\_dir)

 Executes the performance test scripts found in script\_dir on the specified GPU (gpu\_id) and stores the logs in log\_dir.

 - write\_file(file\_path)

 Serializes and saves the current result to the specified file path.

If you find this work useful in your research or applications, please consider citing:

result.title: How GEAK accelerates AI with GPU kernels in Triton - LinkedIn

parts.text:
Sureâ€”let me walk you through Geak (GEAK) as if I were the first author, using the Feynman technique: explain it simply, build intuition, then add detail, and finally show evidence and limitations.

What problem are we solving?
- Writing fast GPU kernels is hard. You typically need a GPU expert to pick tile sizes, manage memory hierarchy, avoid bank conflicts, coalesce loads, and adapt to each GPU architecture. Itâ€™s time-consuming and doesnâ€™t scale with the explosion of AI workloads.
- LLMs can write code, but â€œcorrect and fast Triton kernelsâ€ is a much higher bar than, say, Python scripts. General LLMs tend to produce kernels that donâ€™t compile, donâ€™t pass tests, or run slowly.
- We want an automated system that can: from a brief description, generate Triton kernels that are both correct and performant on AMD Instinct GPUs (MI300X, MI250), then verify them, and iteratively improve themâ€”without a human in the loop.

Our idea in one sentence
- Build an agent around a strong LLM that uses a structured loopâ€”generate, test, reflect, and optimizeâ€”plus inference-time compute scaling (multiple tries, feedback, and parallelization) to steadily turn rough kernel drafts into correct, fast kernels.

Why Triton, and why AMD GPUs?
- Triton is a Python-like DSL designed for kernels; it balances control and readability and is widely adopted.
- AMD Instinct GPUs power many modern AI stacks; to democratize performance across diverse hardware, we need automated kernel generation beyond a single vendor.

What is GEAK (the system)?
Think of GEAK as four cooperating roles around an LLM:

1) Generator
- Takes a short task description (e.g., â€œfused softmax over rows with dropout maskâ€) and any helpful context (a 1-shot similar kernel retrieved by code similarity, and a â€œknowledge packâ€ with Triton and hardware tips).
- Produces an initial Triton kernel.

2) Evaluator
- Stage 1: Functional tests. We compile and run with unit tests and fixtures. If it fails, we collect the error trace and observable outputs.
- Stage 2: If it passes functionally, we run performance tests (latency, memory behavior) against a reference.

3) Reflector
- Reads the failing code plus the error trace and explains what went wrong in plain language (e.g., â€œmismatched block pointer stridesâ€, â€œout-of-bounds due to tile size vs. shapeâ€).
- Proposes a concrete fix strategy. This guards against repeating the same mistake and helps the LLM escape the â€œdebugging trapâ€ where it keeps making the same fix.

4) Optimizer
- When code is correct, we shift to speed. The optimizer sees a ranked history of previous candidates and their timings and proposes a new optimization plan (not code yet): try different BLOCK sizes, vectorized loads, shared memory tiling, software pipelining, persistent threads, avoiding register spills, etc.
- The Generator then implements that plan into a new kernel variant.

Key techniques that make this work
- Inference-time compute scaling: we allocate more effort at inference: multiple iterations, parallel runs (temperature=1 for diversity), and pass@k selection. Accuracy improves roughly log-linearly with more runs.
- Reflexion-style loop: we write down â€œlessons learnedâ€ from crashes and errors into a short-term memory for the next attempt. This dramatically improves debuggability.
- 1-shot retrieval: we retrieve the most similar kernel by code similarity, not instruction similarity. Seeing a concrete, structurally similar Triton kernel is more helpful than a stylistically similar prompt.
- Knowledge injection: we augment prompts with targeted Triton and AMD ROCm/Mi300X tips (e.g., alignment constraints, wavefront sizes, LDS usage patterns, TMA/block pointer idioms, masking semantics).
- Anti-debugging-trap: if an attempt exceeds a max number of reflection cycles without progress, we force a fresh strategy to avoid looping.

What do we evaluate on?
We needed rigorous, GPU-targeted benchmarks that score both correctness and speed. We release two suites:

- TritonBench-revised (184 kernels)
  - Adapted from TritonBench-G; we fixed issues discovered on AMD GPUs (e.g., shared memory errors, HIP argument mismatches, missing function calls, inconsistent test harnesses). This yields a cleaner, stricter correctness signal.
- ROCm Triton Benchmark (30 kernels)
  - Real kernels from open-source AMD ROCm repos (e.g., Triton-based GEMM variants, layernorm, softmax, random ops, sorting/swizzle tests). These reflect practical, expert-authored patterns.

How do we measure?
- Correctness: unit tests must pass end-to-end. We also use pass@k to fairly account for multiple candidates.
- Performance: latency vs. reference on the same shapes/hardware; we report average speedups for correct kernels.

Main results
- Correctness:
  - On TritonBench-revised: up to 54.89% of tasks produce a fully correct kernel (vs. ~15% when directly prompting frontier LLMs without an agent loop).
  - On ROCm Triton Benchmark: up to 63.33% correctness.
- Performance:
  - On TritonBench-revised, GEAK-generated correct kernels achieve average speedup up to 2.59Ã— over reference baselines.
- Scaling:
  - We observe a log-linear scaling law with more inference-time attempts: more parallel/sequential runs â†’ higher pass rates.

What changed vs. naÃ¯ve â€œLLM writes codeâ€?
- The failure mode of direct prompting is â€œcompiles rarely; passes tests even more rarely; performance is an afterthought.â€ GEAKâ€™s loop changes the game:
  - Errors are treated as training signals at inference time.
  - We deliberately separate â€œfix bugsâ€ (reflector) from â€œget fasterâ€ (optimizer), so we donâ€™t prematurely tune performance on broken code.
  - We guide the optimizer with sorted historical candidates, which focuses the LLM on productive directions instead of random tweaks.

A concrete example of the loop
- Task: write a block-pointer matmul variant using Triton for MI300X with FP16 inputs.
  1) Generator drafts a tiling (e.g., BLOCK_M/N/K = 128/128/32) with prefetching and masks for edge tiles.
  2) Evaluator: tests failâ€”incorrect accumulation shape on fringe tiles.
  3) Reflector: identifies incorrect stride usage and masking in the last K-tile; proposes a corrected mask computation and pointer arithmetic.
  4) Generator applies fix â†’ tests pass.
  5) Optimizer: proposes trying different BLOCK_K and vectorized loads (ldmatrix-like patterns), adjusts num_warps, adds software pipelining hints.
  6) Evaluator times variants; the fastest passing kernel is selected.
  7) Parallel runs add diversity; pass@k increases the chance we find both correct and fast solutions.

What we open-sourced
- GEAK-agent: the multi-agent framework with Generator/Reflector/Evaluator/Optimizer, configs, and scripts to run on your data.
- GEAK-eval: the evaluation harnesses for the two benchmarks, including our fixes and standardized tests/perf runners.

Why the results matter
- Portable performance: With an agentic system, teams can target new hardware (here, AMD Instinct GPUs) without paying the full expert-optimization cost each time.
- Productivity: Instead of weeks per kernel, you describe intent and let the agent grind through the debugging and tuning loop automatically.
- Research direction: It shows that inference-time scaling and agentic feedback can substitute for specialized training in many cases, which is promising for â€œAI that accelerates AI.â€

Limitations and whatâ€™s next
- Not all kernels pass yet. Control-flow-heavy or numerically fragile kernels still fail at notable rates.
- Performance tuning is good but not always expert-level. Truly bleeding-edge performance (e.g., micro-architectural tricks, exotic prefetching) may need custom guidance or additional domain tools.
- Model dependence: stronger LLMs help. We experimented with multiple frontier models; results vary by backbone.
- Generalization: we focused on Triton on AMD GPUs; extending to CUDA, HIP bare-metal, or embedded accelerators will need adapted knowledge packs and evaluators.

Planned extensions
- Richer retrieval: structural program analysis to find not only similar code, but similar performance bottlenecks.
- Learned optimizers: have the optimizer learn which strategies worked historically for a given pattern/hardware.
- Multi-objective tuning: jointly optimize for speed, memory footprint, numerical stability, and energy.
- Broader benchmarks: more ROCm kernels and cross-vendor tasks, plus community submissions.

A quick takeaway for practitioners
- If you have a kernel-shaped need in Triton, GEAK can bootstrap you from a short description to a correct, competitive kernel and iterate toward better speed automatically.
- Use 1-shot retrieval, enable reflexion, keep a cap on debugging loops to avoid traps, and run parallel candidates to harvest diversity. Measure with pass@k.

Pointers
- Paper: arXiv:2507.23194
- Agent code: github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-agent
- Evaluation: github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-eval
- Overview blog (ROCm): â€œGEAK: Introducing Triton Kernel AI Agent & Evaluation Benchmarksâ€

If youâ€™d like, tell me a kernel you care about (e.g., attention softmax variant, fused norm+activation), and Iâ€™ll sketch how GEAK would approach generating and tuning it.

messages.content: what is the evaluation pipeline of GEAK

Hereâ€™s the GEAK evaluation pipeline, step by step, focusing on what is measured, how itâ€™s executed, and how results are aggregated.

Inputs
- Task spec: brief natural-language description of the kernel plus shapes/dtypes.
- Reference implementation: PyTorch or Triton baseline for functional parity and timing.
- Hardware: AMD Instinct GPUs (e.g., MI300X/MI250) under ROCm.
- Benchmarks:
  - TritonBench-revised (184 tasks; fixes for AMD-specific issues).
  - ROCm Triton Benchmark (30 real kernels from ROCm repos).

Pipeline stages
1) Candidate generation (pass@k setting)
- The agent produces multiple kernel candidates per task using its generateâ€“reflectâ€“optimize loop.
- Diversity via different temperatures/seeds and strategy plans.
- Each candidate is independently evaluated (below). Final scoring uses pass@k.

2) Functional verification
- Compile: Try to JIT-compile the Triton kernel. Capture compile-time errors.
- Run unit tests: Deterministic test harness executes the kernel across prescribed shapes.
- Correctness checks:
  - Numerical: compare outputs vs. reference using dtype-appropriate tolerances (e.g., FP16/FP32 epsilons) and mask handling on edge tiles.
  - Shape/stride/layout: ensure correct output shapes, strides, and no OOB accesses (masking).
- Result: candidate is marked functionally correct only if all tests pass without runtime errors.

3) Performance evaluation (only for functionally correct candidates)
- Warmup: multiple warmup runs to stabilize caches and clocks.
- Timing: multiple measured runs; report median or trimmed mean latency to reduce noise.
- Baseline comparison: compute speedup versus the reference implementation for the same shapes/dtypes.
- Resource sanity checks: optional counters to detect register spill anomalies or pathological LDS use when available.

4) Iterative reflection and optimization (within an evaluation budget)
- If a candidate fails:
  - Error triage: collect compiler/runtime traces and mismatched tensor stats.
  - Reflection note: summarize root cause (e.g., incorrect pointer arithmetic, mask, stride).
  - Regenerate with a targeted fix; repeat functional verification.
- If a candidate passes but is slow:
  - Optimization plan: propose concrete tweaks (BLOCK sizes, num_warps, vectorized loads, pipelining, tiling).
  - Generate new variants and re-time them.
- Anti-stall guard: cap iterations per task; if no progress, force a fresh strategy or stop.

5) Aggregation and metrics
- Correctness:
  - pass@1 and pass@k: fraction of tasks for which at least one of k candidates is functionally correct.
- Performance:
  - For tasks with at least one correct candidate, report best-achieved speedup over baseline.
  - Summaries: average and median speedup across solved tasks; optionally success-weighted averages.
- Scaling curves:
  - Plot correctness vs. inference-time budget (number of attempts/parallelism) to show scaling behavior.

Reproducibility controls
- Fixed seeds per attempt class; logged prompts, retrieved exemplars, and reflection notes.
- Pinned ROCm/Triton versions, kernel launch configs, and benchmark inputs.
- Standardized harness:
  - Identical tensor initializers and dtype handling.
  - Consistent tolerance thresholds per op/dtype.
  - Uniform timing protocol across tasks.

Outputs per benchmark
- TritonBench-revised:
  - pass@k correctness rates.
  - Speedup distribution for solved tasks.
- ROCm Triton Benchmark:
  - Same metrics, highlighting real-world kernels.

In short: GEAK evaluates each generated kernel through compile â†’ unit tests â†’ timed runs; uses failures as feedback to produce improved candidates; and reports pass@k correctness and speedups against reference baselines under a controlled ROCm/Triton harness.

result.content:
## AI-Powered Library for Researchers

### Track research interests, scroll daily paper feeds with AI summary, and chat with bulk of files.

1. [Geak: Introducing Triton Kernel AI Agent & Evaluation Benchmarks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2507.23194)

cs.CLcs.LGcs.AI01 Aug 2025

Jianghui Wang, Vinay Joshi, Saptarshi Majumder, Xu Chao, Bin Ding, Ziqiong Liu, Pratik Prabhanjan Brahma, Dong Li, Zicheng Liu, Emad Barsoum

Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD)

The demand for AI-generated GPU kernels is rapidly growing, influenced by the need for scalable, hardware-optimized solutions in both industry and academia. As deep learning workloads grow in complexity and diversity, it is imperative to automate low-level kernel development to meet performance and productivity demands. Major cloud providers, semiconductor companies, and research institutions are now investing heavily in AI-driven code generation for GPUs, aiming to reduce manual optimization efforts while achieving near-expert performance on hardware like AMD MI300X. The Triton language, a Python-based DSL for GPU programming, has emerged as a popular target for such AI-generated kernels due to its balance of performance and ease-of-coding. In this work, we present an evaluation suite for Triton-based GPU kernels and GEAK (Generating Efficient AI-centric GPU Kernels)-a framework that leverages cutting-edge LLMs to generate performant Triton code specifically for AMD GPUs, including the AMD MI300X and MI250. GEAK leverages inference-time compute scaling to produce Triton-based GPU kernels using a reasoning loop adapted from Reflexion-style feedback mechanisms. On two evaluation benchmarks, GEAK significantly outperformed the baselines of directly prompting frontier LLMs as well as Reflexion-based generation pipelines by achieving correctness up to $63$% and execution speed up of up to $2.59$X. These results highlight the promise of GEAK-like agentic code generation for accelerating the adoption of diverse hardware platforms and democratizing access to expert-level kernel performance.

messages.content: now do they use LLM as optimizer

Yes. In GEAK, the optimizer is an LLM-driven role.

- Separation of concerns: GEAK splits â€œmake it correctâ€ and â€œmake it fast.â€ Once a candidate passes functional tests, the Optimizer role kicks in.
- Optimizerâ€™s job: The LLM reads the history of prior candidates (configs, perf measurements, error notes) and proposes a concrete optimization plan, not just vague advice. Typical levers:
  - Tile sizes: BLOCK_M/BLOCK_N/BLOCK_K, num_warps, num_stages
  - Memory: vectorized/global loads-stores, shared/LDS tiling, block pointers/TMA patterns, prefetch distance
  - Execution: software pipelining, persistent threads, unrolling, avoiding register spill
  - Edge handling: masking strategy for fringe tiles to reduce divergence
- Loop mechanics: The plan is handed back to the Generator (also LLM-guided) to implement as a new kernel variant, which is then re-benchmarked. The Optimizer uses the ranked timings of recent variants to steer the next plan toward promising regions rather than random tweaks.
- Inference-time scaling: Multiple optimizer-guided variants are explored in parallel (different seeds/temperatures), and the best passing kernel is selected (pass@k and best speedup).

So, the optimization phase is agentic and LLM-led: the LLM reasons about performance trade-offs and proposes targeted Triton-level changes, guided by measured feedback.

messages.content: what is the limit of debugging attempts?

They cap it with a configurable parameter to avoid the â€œdebugging trap.â€

- Name: max_perf_debug_num
- Meaning: maximum number of reflection/debugging attempts allowed for a given code path before the agent must abandon that approach.
- Behavior: if a kernel keeps failing after hitting this limit, GEAK discards the current strategy and forces the LLM to generate a fresh plan and new code, rather than looping on the same bug.

The exact numeric value isnâ€™t fixed by the paper; itâ€™s a tunable setting in the framework/configs.

# GEAK: Introducing Triton Kernel AI Agent & Evaluation Benchmarks

## Contents

# GEAK: Introducing Triton Kernel AI Agent & Evaluation Benchmarks [\#](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/rocm.blogs.amd.com\#geak-introducing-triton-kernel-ai-agent-evaluation-benchmarks)

August 01, 2025 by [Jianghui Wang](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/jianghui-wang.html), [Vinay Joshi](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/vinay-joshi.html), [Saptarshi Majumder](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/saptarshi-majumder.html), [Chao Xu](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/chao-xu.html), [Bin Ding](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/bin-ding.html), [Ziqiong Liu](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/ziqiong-liu.html), [Pratik Prabhanjan Brahma](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/pratik-prabhanjan-brahma.html), [Dong Li](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/dong-li.html), [Zicheng Liu](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/zicheng-liu.html), [Emad Barsoum](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/authors/emad-barsoum.html).

10 min read. \| 2414 total words.

[Software tools & optimizations](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/blog/category/software-tools-optimizations.html)

[AI/ML](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/blog/tag/aiml.html)

[Developers](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/developers.html), [AI](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/ai.html)

At AMD, we are pioneering ways to accelerate AI development using AI itself, by generating accurate and efficient GPU kernels. Specifically, we are starting with the automatic generation of kernels in [Triton](https://triton-lang.org/main/index.html), an open-source Python-like language for writing parallel programming code for GPUs. Today, AMD is excited to announce (a) [Generating Efficient AI-centric Kernels (GEAK)](https://github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-Agent) for AMD GPUs, and results on (b) two Triton kernel evaluation benchmarks, where we show how AI agents can perform inference-time scaling with frontier LLMs to generate accurate and efficient kernels for AMD Instinctâ„¢ GPUs like MI250X and MI300X.

**Key Takeaways:**

- Announcing [GEAK Triton kernel generation framework](https://github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-Agent), a library of various types of agentic AI and scaling methods to automatically produce Triton kernels from just brief instructions of its intended functionality.

- Announcing corresponding [GEAK Triton Kernel Evaluation Benchmarks](https://github.com/AMD-AIG-AIMA/GEAK-eval), consisting of a modified set of 184 kernels originally sourced from [TritonBench-G](https://arxiv.org/abs/2502.14752) \[1\] and an additional set of 30 kernels from various open [ROCm repositories](https://github.com/ROCm).

- Execution accuracy up to 54.89% on TritonBench-modified and 63.33% on ROCm benchmark (as compared to around 15% when directly prompting frontier LLMs) in producing correct kernels that pass all the unit tests.

- Average Speedup of up to 2.59X with the AI-generated kernels over reference kernels from the TritonBench-modified benchmark.


Figure 1. Overview of the GEAK kernel code generation AI agent [#](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/rocm.blogs.amd.com#id1)

As shown in Figure 1, the agentic AI system comprises four core modules: a **generator**, a **reflector**, an **evaluator**, and an **optimizer**.

- The **generator** produces code based on user query and contextual information.

- The **evaluator** follows a cascaded design: it first performs a functionality test to verify correctness. If the code fails this test, the corresponding error trace is fed back to the reflector for further analysis. If the code passes, the evaluator proceeds to assess its performance, including latency and memory efficiency.

- If the generated code fails to execute correctly, the **reflector** analyzes both the code and the resulting error trace to identify potential issues.

- Finally, the **optimizer** takes as input the functionally correct code and formulates strategies to enhance its performance with respect to latency and computational efficiency.


To improve the performance of our agent, we employ some composable and configurable techniques as mentioned below:

- **1-shot Prompting**


To enable 1-shot prompting, the most similar Triton code from existing datasets is used in the prompt. The datasets used for 1-shot prompt do not overlap with the benchmark. Weâ€™ve observed that 1-shot sample retrieval from datasets is most effective when using code similarity rather than instruction similarity.

- **Knowledge Injection**


We enhance the prompt with domain-specific knowledge on writing efficient Triton kernels, including detailed hardware specifications. This incorporation of low-level optimization principles significantly improves the accuracy and quality of LLM-generated code.

- **Reflexion**


To enhance the systemâ€™s self-correcting capabilities, we leverage a reflexion \[3\] module that supports introspective debugging and iterative refinement. When an LLM-generated kernel fails the functionality test, the resulting error trace is provided as feedback to the reflector for further analysis and correction. The agent is tasked with analyzing the cause of failure and proposing a corresponding solution. We scale the number of iterations to improve kernel generation.

- **LLM selection for kernel agent**


We have explored the use of multiple LLMs like GPT-4.1, GPT-o1, and Gemini 2.5 Pro. We observed notable variations in the output produced by different models, indicating that the capability of the underlying LLM can substantially influence the results. In this blog, we present results with GPT-4.1 only but the GEAK codebase allows developers to try different LLMs as per their choice.

- **LLM as Optimizer**


The optimizer is tasked with identifying potential optimization directions based on previous code generations and their corresponding performance metrics. These historical records, which include the generated code and associated performance results, are sorted in ascending order of performance. This structured presentation \[2\] helps guide the LLM toward proposing more effective optimization strategies.

- **Debugging Trap**


When LLMâ€™s generated code has bugs, the error trace is provided to the Reflector for feedback generation for further correction. However, weâ€™ve observed that sometimes code can undergo several reflection cycles while still being plagued by the same bug, which is what we refer to as the debugging trap. To prevent the agent from getting stuck in a debugging trap, we impose a limit on the number of debugging attempts per code snippet using a parameter max\_perf\_debug\_num. If the code continues to fail after reaching this threshold, the agent is required to discard the current approach and generate a new strategy along with fresh code.

- **Parallel Scaling**


To ensure reliable kernel generation, we run multiple instances of GEAK multiple times in parallel and independently. To introduce diversity in the generated code, the LLM output is sampled with the parameter temperature set to 1. Our experiments show that such diversity in generation can yield correct and faster kernels that are otherwise underexplored. Moreover, further experiments indicate that combining sequential and parallel scaling yields additional performance improvements. To obtain unbiased estimates of accuracy, we use the pass@k metric to estimate it \[4\].

## Triton Kernel Evaluation Benchmark [\#](https://rocm.blogs.amd.com/rocm.blogs.amd.com\#triton-kernel-evaluation-benchmark)

We conducted experiments using two benchmarks methods:

**1\. TritonBench-Modified Benchmark (184 Kernels):**

The Triton kernels and corresponding evaluation codebase were adapted from [TritonBench](https://github.com/thunlp/TritonBench) \[1\] with several modifications made:

- Out of 184 kernels in TritonBench-G, we identified and corrected errors in 37 kernels that were encountered when running on AMD GPUs. These errors include shared memory errors, invalid HIP arguments, and ModuleNotFound errors.

- We found that several kernels in the original TritonBench repository missed necessary call functions, which resulted in the accuracy checking code comparing empty strings as output. We corrected this and ensured that the correct common seed was used during test.

- For some kernels, testbenches were written inconsistently that produced unexpected outputs. We have fixed these kernels to have consistent testbenches.


**2\. ROCm Repository Triton Benchmark (30 Kernels):**

The benchmark contains 30 kernels chosen from various open ROCm repositories that have been written by Triton expert engineers and released publicly to help enable the ecosystem around running AI workloads efficiently on AMD GPUs. The entire list of kernels is outlined in Table 1. We also took assistance from frontier LLMs to put these kernels, as well as their corresponding unit tests, in the same format as the TritonBench-modified framework. It allows us to compare the accuracy and efficiency of our agent consistently.

| **ROCm Kernel** | **Repository link** |
| --- | --- |
| 1\. test\_tma\_store\_gemm 2. moe-gemm 3. layernorm 4. triton\_multreduce\_matmul\_kernel.py 5. multreduce\_matmul\_dot\_kernel.py 6. gemm 7. test\_block\_pointer\_matmul 8. test\_block\_copy 9. test\_add\_kernel 10. softmax | [ROCm/triton](https://github.com/ROCm/triton/tree/main_perf) |
| 1\. mnsnorm\_fwd 2. rmsnorm\_bwd 3. test\_chained\_dot\_fp8 4. test\_matmul\_MXFP 5. test\_gemm\_fusion | [ROCm/aiter](https://github.com/ROCm/aiter) |
| 1\. test\_triton\_swizzle2d 2. test\_triton\_sort 3. test\_triton\_flip 4. test\_reverse\_range | [ROCm/aotriton](https://github.com/ROCm/aotriton) |
| 1\. test\_load\_reduce.py 2. test\_chained\_matmul | [ROCm/vllm](https://github.com/ROCm/vllm) |
| 1\. test\_random\_int 2. test\_randn 3. test\_kernel\_sub 4. test\_kernel\_dot 5. test\_batched
result.summary:
The webpage introduces the GEAK (Generating Efficient AI-centric Kernels) framework, developed by AMD, which utilizes AI to automatically generate efficient GPU kernels in Triton, a parallel programming language. Key highlights include:

- **GEAK Framework**: A library designed to produce Triton kernels from brief functional instructions, enhancing AI development for AMD GPUs.
- **Evaluation Benchmarks**: The framework includes two benchmark sets, with execution accuracy reaching 54.89% on modified TritonBench and 63.33% on ROCm benchmarks, significantly improving upon the 15% accuracy when using frontier LLMs directly.
- **Performance Improvements**: AI-generated kernels show an average speedup of up to 2.59 times compared to reference kernels.
- **Core Modules**: The system consists of a generator, evaluator, reflector, and optimizer, working together to produce and refine kernel code based on user input and performance metrics.

Overall, GEAK aims to streamline the process of kernel generation, making it more efficient and accessible for developers working with AMD's GPU architecture.

## AI-Powered Library for Researchers

### Track research interests, scroll daily paper feeds with AI summary, and chat with bulk of files.

1. [Geak: Introducing Triton Kernel AI Agent & Evaluation Benchmarks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2507.23194)

cs.CLcs.LGcs.AI01 Aug 2025

Jianghui Wang, Vinay Joshi, Saptarshi Majumder, Xu Chao, Bin Ding, Ziqiong Liu, Pratik Prabhanjan Brahma, Dong Li, Zicheng Liu, Emad Barsoum

Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD)

The demand for AI-generated GPU kernels is rapidly growing, influenced by the need for scalable, hardware-optimized solutions in both industry and academia. As deep learning workloads grow in complexity and diversity, it is imperative to automate low-level kernel development to meet performance and productivity demands. Major cloud providers, semiconductor companies, and research institutions are now investing heavily in AI-driven code generation for GPUs, aiming to reduce manual optimization efforts while achieving near-expert performance on hardware like AMD MI300X. The Triton language, a Python-based DSL for GPU programming, has emerged as a popular target for such AI-generated kernels due to its balance of performance and ease-of-coding. In this work, we present an evaluation suite for Triton-based GPU kernels and GEAK (Generating Efficient AI-centric GPU Kernels)-a framework that leverages cutting-edge LLMs to generate performant Triton code specifically for AMD GPUs, including the AMD MI300X and MI250. GEAK leverages inference-time compute scaling to produce Triton-based GPU kernels using a reasoning loop adapted from Reflexion-style feedback mechanisms. On two evaluation benchmarks, GEAK significantly outperformed the baselines of directly prompting frontier LLMs as well as Reflexion-based generation pipelines by achieving correctness up to $63$% and execution speed up of up to $2.59$X. These results highlight the promise of GEAK-like agentic code generation for accelerating the adoption of diverse hardware platforms and democratizing access to expert-level kernel performance.

Illustration of GEAK pipeline.

With the increasing complexity of deep learning workloads, GEAK aims to enhance performance and productivity by leveraging large language models (LLMs) to produce efficient Triton code. The framework employs a reasoning loop inspired by Reflexion-style feedback mechanisms, achieving notable improvements in correctness (up to 63%) and execution speed (up to 2.59 times faster) compared to traditional methods. The evaluation suite for Triton-based GPU kernels demonstrates the potential of GEAK to democratize access to expert-level kernel performance and accelerate the adoption of diverse hardware platforms. The GEAK utilizes inference-time scaling to produce high-performance, numerically accurate kernels, achieving significant improvements in execution accuracy and speed. Specifically, it reports an average execution accuracy of 54.89% on modified Triton benchmarks and 63.33% on ROCm benchmarks, with a speedup of 2.59 times over baseline performance. The post expresses pride in the team's achievements and invites the community to try out the new tool.

parts.text:
They cap it with a configurable parameter to avoid the â€œdebugging trap.â€

- Name: max_perf_debug_num
- Meaning: maximum number of reflection/debugging attempts allowed for a given code path before the agent must abandon that approach.
- Behavior: if a kernel keeps failing after hitting this limit, GEAK discards the current strategy and forces the LLM to generate a fresh plan and new code, rather than looping on the same bug.

The exact numeric value isnâ€™t fixed by the paper; itâ€™s a tunable setting in the framework/configs.

messages.content: what would happen if the maximum was hit?

When the max debugging-attempts threshold is reached (max_perf_debug_num), GEAK deliberately â€œcuts the cordâ€ on the current line of attack and pivots. Concretely:

- Stop the current fix loop: The reflector-led debug cycle for that code path is terminated. No more retries applying incremental patches to the same buggy kernel.
- Discard the stalled strategy: The agent treats the current approach (its plan, tiling choices, masking logic, etc.) as exhausted.
- Force a fresh restart with a new plan: The system prompts the LLM to produce a new high-level strategy and regenerate code from scratch (often with altered tiling, memory layout, masking, or algorithmic choices), then resumes evaluate â†’ reflect/optimize on that new branch.
- Budget-aware progression: If the overall per-task attempt budget is still available, the new branch is evaluated like any other candidate. If the global budget is exhausted, the task is marked unsolved for that run.

Why this matters: it prevents the â€œdebugging trap,â€ where the agent keeps cycling on the same bug without making structural changes. By resetting the plan, GEAK increases diversity and the chance of escaping a local failure mode.

pip install triton-runner==0.2.2Copy PIP instructions

[Latest version](https://pypi.org/project/triton-runner/)

Released: Sep 20, 2025

Triton multi-level runner, include IR/PTX/cubin.

[Report project as malware](https://pypi.org/project/triton-runner/submit-malware-report/)

## Project description

### Multi-Level Triton Runner Tool ðŸ”§

[**Documentation**](https://pypi.org/doc/) ï½œ [**ðŸ”— triton-runner.org**](https://triton-runner.org)

**English** \| [**ä¸­æ–‡**](https://pypi.org/README.zh.md)

triton-runner is a lightweight, multi-level execution engine for [OpenAI/Triton](https://github.com/triton-lang/triton), designed to support IR/PTX/cubin launches in complex pass pipelines.

triton-runner is compatible with **Triton v3.4.0 (primary), v3.3.x, v3.2.0, v3.1.0 or v3.0.0**, and may not work with other versions.

## âœ¨ Features

- [I. multi-level execution](https://pypi.org/pypi.org#i-multi-level-execution)
- [II. ðŸ’¡use cubin runner to solve Triton issue](https://pypi.org/pypi.org#ii-use-cubin-runner-to-solve-triton-issue)
- [III. TTIR Debug](https://pypi.org/pypi.org#iii-ttir-debug)
- [IV. Benchmark performance](https://pypi.org/pypi.org#iv-benchmarks)

## ðŸ“¦ Installation

### Quick Installation

You can install the latest stable release of Triton from pip.

```
pipinstalltriton-runner

```

### Install from source

You can install from source to access the latest features and developments.

```
gitclonehttps://github.com/OpenMLIR/triton-runner
cdtriton-runner

pipinstall-e.

```

## ðŸš€ Quick Start

See the provided examples in the [triton-runner.org](https://triton-runner.org) repository for your first run.

### I. multi-level execution

Almost all of Tritonâ€™s compilation levels are supported by triton-runner. [Gluon](https://github.com/triton-lang/triton/tree/main/python/tutorials/gluon) will be supported soon.

```
---
title: Triton Compilation Pipeline
---
flowchart LR

 subgraph Triton
 A["Python Triton"]:::supported --> B["TTIR Triton IR"]:::supported
 B --> C["TTGIR Triton GPU IR"]:::supported
 C --> D["LLIR LLVM IR"]:::supported

 Gluon["Python Gluon"]:::unsupported --> C
 end

 subgraph Backend
 D --> E["PTX"]:::supported
 E --> F["cubin CUDA Binary"]:::supported
 end

 classDef supported fill:#AED6F1,stroke:#2E86C1,stroke-width:2px,color:#000000;
 classDef unsupported fill:#F5B7B1,stroke:#C0392B,stroke-width:2px,color:#000000;

```

#### 1\. Python runner

You can run your Triton code using `@triton_runner.jit` instead of `@triton.jit`. See an example in [examples/python\_runner/matmul.py](https://github.com/OpenMLIR/triton-runner/blob/main/examples/python_runner/matmul.py#L12)

You can run the example with `python examples/python_runner/matmul.py`. After running successfully, you should see output like `[triton-runner] Triton cache saved`.

#### 2\. TTIR runner

In addition to using `@triton_runner.jit` instead of `@triton.jit`, you also need to provide the TTIR file. You can place it in the same directory as the current Python file and use `ttir_dir=triton_runner.get_file_dir(__file__)`. See an example in [examples/ttir\_runner/matmul.py](https://github.com/OpenMLIR/triton-runner/blob/main/examples/ttir_runner/matmul.py#L67). Alternatively, you can use the Triton cache directory generated by the Python runner(previous step).

You can run the example with `python examples/ttir_runner/matmul.py`.

#### 3\. TTGIR/LLIR/PTX/cubin runner

In addition to using `@triton_runner.jit` instead of `@triton.jit`, you also need to provide the corresponding file. Like the TTGIR runner, You can place it in the same directory as the current Python file and use `ttgir_dir=triton_runner.get_file_dir(__file__)`. Since all of them are architecture-specific, be sure to use the corresponding metadata JSON file. See an example in [examples/ttgir\_runner/sm90/matmul-with-tma-v4.py](https://github.com/OpenMLIR/triton-runner/blob/main/examples/ttgir_runner/sm90/matmul-with-tma-v4.py#L76).

If your architecture is `sm90`(Hopper), you can run the example using the TTGIR runner with `python examples/ttgir_runner/sm90/matmul-with-tma-v4.py`.

#### 4\. Hopper examples with Triton v3.4.0

I provide examples for different architectures and Triton versions. Here's example commands for multi-level targeting `sm90 (H100, H200, H20, etc.)` with Triton v3.4.0.

```
pythonexamples/python_runner/matmul.py

pythonexamples/ttir_runner/matmul.py

pythonexamples/ttgir_runner/sm90/matmul-with-tma-v4.py

pythonexamples/llir_runner/sm90/matmul-with-tma-v4.py

pythonexamples/ptx_runner/sm90/matmul-with-tma-v4.py

pythonexamples/cubin_runner/sm90/matmul-with-tma-v4.py

```

#### 5\. More architectures examples

Now provide examples for architectures include `sm90 (H100, H200, H20, etc.)`, `sm80 (A100, A30)`, `sm120 (RTX PRO 6000, RTX 5090, etc.)`, `sm86 (A10, RTX 3090, etc.)` or `sm75 (T4, RTX 2080, etc.)`. For these targets, please refer to [examples](https://pypi.org/doc/examples_v3.4.0.md).

If your GPU does not have one of the above compute capabilities, you can use `TRITON_CACHE_DIR=$PWD/.cache` to output the Triton cache to the current directory, and use this kernel cache directory to run your program.

#### 6\. More Triton version examples

If your Triton version is v3.3.1 or v3.3.0, please refer to [examples\_v3.3.x](https://pypi.org/doc/examples_v3.3.x.md) for example commands. If your Triton version is v3.2.0, please refer to [examples\_v3.2.0](https://pypi.org/doc/examples_v3.2.0.md) for example commands. If your Triton version is v3.1.0, please refer to [examples\_v3.1.0](https://pypi.org/doc/examples_v3.1.0.md) for example commands. If your Triton version is v3.0.0, please refer to [examples\_v3.0.0](https://pypi.org/doc/examples_v3.0.0.md) for example commands.

### II. use cubin runner to solve Triton issue

To solve Tritonâ€™s performance and shared memory issues as shown in the [triton\_issue](https://pypi.org/triton_issue) folder, we use the cubin runner.

### III. TTIR Debug

Debugging is supported for TTIR ops like `tt.load`, `arith.addf`, and `tt.trans` in Triton v3.4.0. Here are some example commands for debugging.

```
pythondebug_tool/ttir/01-vector_add/debug_load.py
pythondebug_tool/ttir/01-vector_add/debug_addf.py

pythondebug_tool/ttir/02-matrix_transpose/debug_2d_load.py
pythondebug_tool/ttir/02-matrix_transpose/debug_2d_trans.py

pythondebug_tool/ttir/03-matrix_multiplication/debug_acc.py

pythondebug_tool/ttir/04-softmax/debug_maxnumf.py
pythondebug_tool/ttir/04-softmax/debug_addf-sum.py
pythondebug_tool/ttir/04-softmax/debug_subf.py
pythondebug_tool/ttir/04-softmax/debug_exp-exp_shifted.py
pythondebug_tool/ttir/04-softmax/debug_divf-normalize_by_sum.py

pythondebug_tool/ttir/05-softmax_lse/debug_log_acc.py
pythondebug_tool/ttir/05-softmax_lse/debug_max_acc.py
pythondebug_tool/ttir/05-softmax_lse/debug_more.py

pythondebug_tool/ttir/06-attention/debug_out.py

pythondebug_tool/ttir/07-debug_not_f32/debug_bf16.py

```

### IV. Benchmarks

Benchmarks Referencing [TritonBench](https://github.com/pytorch-labs/tritonbench)

- `launch_latency`: Measures kernel launch overhead.
- `matmul`: Provides a benchmark for matrix multiplication performance.

```
pythonbenchmark/launch_latency/bench.py

pythonbenchmark/static_shape/matmul.py

```
